ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

  1. See Web technology for developers
  2. See JavaScript
  3. See JavaScript reference
  4. See JavaScript error reference
  5. ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

See also

  • Scope
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

See also

  • Scope
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

  1. See Web technology for developers
  2. See JavaScript
  3. See JavaScript reference
  4. See JavaScript error reference
  5. ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

On this Page

  • Message
  • Error type
  • What went wrong?
  • Examples
  • See also
  • Related topics

The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

  1. See Web technology for developers
  2. See JavaScript
  3. See JavaScript reference

  5. ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

See also

  • Scope
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

On this Page

  • Message
  • Error type
  • What went wrong?
  • Examples
  • See also
  • Related topics

The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

See also

  • Scope
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

  • Examples

The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

See also

  • Scope
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

innerHtml:
The JavaScript exception "variable is not defined" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

Message

ReferenceError: "x" is not defined

Error type

ReferenceError.

What went wrong?

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as "$". Put the <script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

Examples

Variable not declared

foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined

The "foo" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

var foo = 'bar';
foo.substring(1); // "ar"

Wrong scope

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

function numbers() { 
  var num1 = 2, 
      num2 = 3;
  return num1 + num2;
}

console.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

var num1 = 2,
    num2 = 3;

function numbers() {
  return num1 + num2; 
}

console.log(numbers()); // 5

See also

  • Scope
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

window._react_data = JSON.parse("{\"locale\":\"en-US\",\"stringCatalog\":{},\"pluralExpression\":null,\"url\":\"/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined?utm_source=mozilla&utm_medium=firefox-console-errors&utm_campaign=default\",\"documentData\":{\"locale\":\"en-US\",\"slug\":\"Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined\",\"enSlug\":\"Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined\",\"id\":185418,\"title\":\"ReferenceError: \\\"x\\\" is not defined\",\"summary\":\"The JavaScript exception \\\"variable is not defined\\\" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.\",\"language\":\"English (US)\",\"hrefLang\":\"en\",\"absoluteURL\":\"/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined\",\"wikiURL\":\"https://wiki.developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined\",\"editURL\":\"https://wiki.developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined$edit\",\"translateURL\":\"https://wiki.developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Not_defined$locales\",\"translationStatus\":null,\"bodyHTML\":\"
\\n\\n

The JavaScript exception \\\"variable is not defined\\\" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

\\n\\n

Message

\\n\\n
ReferenceError: \\\"x\\\" is not defined\\n
\\n\\n

Error type

\\n\\n

ReferenceError.

\\n\\n

What went wrong?

\\n\\n

There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

\\n\\n
\\n

Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as \\\"$\\\". Put the element is used to embed or reference executable code; this is typically used to embed or refer to JavaScript code.\\\"><script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

\\n
\\n\\n

Examples

\\n\\n

Variable not declared

\\n\\n
foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined\\n
\\n\\n

The \\\"foo\\\" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the String.prototype.substring() method will work.

\\n\\n
var foo = 'bar';\\nfoo.substring(1); // \\\"ar\\\"
\\n\\n

Wrong scope

\\n\\n

A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

\\n\\n
function numbers() { \\n  var num1 = 2, \\n      num2 = 3;\\n  return num1 + num2;\\n}\\n\\nconsole.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.
\\n\\n

However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

\\n\\n
var num1 = 2,\\n    num2 = 3;\\n\\nfunction numbers() {\\n  return num1 + num2; \\n}\\n\\nconsole.log(numbers()); // 5
\\n\\n

See also

\\n\\n
    \\n
  • Scope
    • \\n
  • Declaring variables in the JavaScript Guide
    • \\n
  • Function scope in the JavaScript Guide

    \\n\\n

    The JavaScript exception \\\"variable is not defined\\\" occurs when there is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere.

    \\n\\n

    Message

    \\n\\n
    ReferenceError: \\\"x\\\" is not defined\\n
    \\n\\n

    Error type

    \\n\\n

    {{jsxref(\\\"ReferenceError\\\")}}.

    \\n\\n

    What went wrong?

    \\n\\n

    There is a non-existent variable referenced somewhere. This variable needs to be declared, or you need to make sure it is available in your current script or scope.

    \\n\\n
    \\n

    Note: When loading a library (such as jQuery), make sure it is loaded before you access library variables, such as \\\"$\\\". Put the element is used to embed or reference executable code; this is typically used to embed or refer to JavaScript code.\\\"><script> tag that loads the library before your code that uses it.

    \\n
    \\n\\n

    Examples

    \\n\\n

    Variable not declared

    \\n\\n
    foo.substring(1); // ReferenceError: foo is not defined\\n
    \\n\\n

    The \\\"foo\\\" variable isn't defined anywhere. It needs to be some string, so that the {{jsxref(\\\"String.prototype.substring()\\\")}} method will work.

    \\n\\n
    var foo = 'bar';\\nfoo.substring(1); // \\\"ar\\\"
    \\n\\n

    Wrong scope

    \\n\\n

    A variable needs to be available in the current context of execution. Variables defined inside a function cannot be accessed from anywhere outside the function, because the variable is defined only in the scope of the function

    \\n\\n
    function numbers() { \\n  var num1 = 2, \\n      num2 = 3;\\n  return num1 + num2;\\n}\\n\\nconsole.log(num1); // ReferenceError num1 is not defined.
    \\n\\n

    However, a function can access all variables and functions defined inside the scope in which it is defined. In other words, a function defined in the global scope can access all variables defined in the global scope.

    \\n\\n
    var num1 = 2,\\n    num2 = 3;\\n\\nfunction numbers() {\\n  return num1 + num2; \\n}\\n\\nconsole.log(numbers()); // 5
    \\n\\n

    See also

    \\n\\n
